active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Secure Design Principles. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards on 'Security vs. Performance Trade-offs' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security Architecture And Engineering > Secure Design Principles > Threat Modeling and Risk-Based Design > Risk-Based Design Decisions > Security vs. Performance Trade-offs). Incorporate these elements: - Learning Objectives: [Paste the full learning_objectives array here]. - Active Learning: Inspire cards that prep for [discussion, peer teaching, problem-solving as listed]. - Scaffolding: Distribute cards: 30% Layer 1, 25% Layer 2, 25% Layer 3, 20% Layer 4. - Prior Knowledge: Assume familiarity with CIA triad, threat modeling, perf metrics. Full Research Context: [Core Concepts: Security (CIA protection), Performance (latency/throughput/etc.), Trade-offs, Trustworthiness (NIST SP 800-160)]. [NIST SP 800-160 v1/v2: Systems engineering; trade space balances security/performance/cost. Full: https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.SP.800-160v1r1]. [NIST SP 800-63-3: Digital Identity; AAL1 (low friction, basic security), AAL2 (multi-factor, moderate perf hit), AAL3 (hardware, high security/low perf). Trade-offs: Higher AAL boosts confidentiality/integrity but reduces availability via latency/friction. Full: https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.SP.800-63-3]. [Other: NIST SP 800-207 Zero Trust (micro-segmentation trades perf for granularity). OWASP Secure Design Principles.] Sources: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-160v1r1.pdf, https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63-3.html, https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.SP.800-207. Follow Flashcard Schema exactly: Mix Basic Q/A (40%), Cloze (30%), MCQ (30%). Use distractor protocol. Each card JSON: {'type': '...', 'front': '...', 'back': '...', 'tags': '[Layer:X][Bloom:Y][Source:Z]'}. Output as numbered list of JSON objects. Ensure university-level: active recall, misconceptions addressed, higher-order thinking.
